IMO The most interesting thing about transmissible cancers is its philosophical implications. It's derived from Tasmanian devil cells, but it's functioning like it's own entity and species. It is subject to selection and evolution, and if it manages to get into other species (like venereal cancer in dogs already has) then it's no longer tied to the fate of Tasmanian devils. It really puts into question our understanding of what constitutes an organism.

Hi Destin, I love your videos but I don't think you realised what is really extraordinary about devil facial tumour disease. A cancer with 100% death rate isn't a surprise, without modern medicine this would be commonplace. A contagious cancer is staggering, absolutely incredible. If I took a cancer cell from one patient and put it in another patient's body, the second patient would almost certainly kill that cancer because their immune system would recognise it as foreign. Cancer cells are modified versions of your own cells, unique to the individual. Just like if patient 1 donates a kidney to patient 2 the immune system of patient 2 will attack the donated tissue, it should also attack a cancer donated by patient 1. This is due to a group of proteins called the major histocompatibility complex, which help trigger the immune system's attack on foreign cells (or your own cells infected by foreign material, eg viruses).

Humans have many proteins which are the same across the whole population, but the MHC is incredibly diverse. With the exception of identical twins, no two individuals have the same MHC combinations. Tassie Devils on the other hand have very few combinations, to the point where a tassie devil could probably have a kidney transplant without any anti-rejection drugs. They don't recognise the cells from another devil as foreign, so they don't recognise the tumour as foreign either.

Hope you don't mind me commenting, I learn so many things from all your videos, it's quietly pleasing to be able to pass some knowledge back. Maybe the immune system would make a good topic for another video?

Regards, Dan

This is why genetic diversity is important, guys. Tasmanian Devils have very little variation in their gene pool -- so little, in fact, that cells from one devil won't get rejected by the immune system of another. Same thing happens in cheetahs, though fortunately no disease has arisen to take advantage of it. Humans, meanwhile, have to basically kill off their immune systems in order to receive organs and the like. So these cancer cells can easily spread; once they mutated to evade one devil's immune system, they could evade them all. It's also doubtful that a devil will EVER be immune by chance -- they're just too similar to each other. The contagious cancer is sadly a symptom of a deeper problem.

The release of the first immunised, captive-bred Tasmanian devils into the wild has been hailed as a turning point in the fight against the disease which threatens to wipe them out.

Tasmanian devil populations have been devastated by a fatal facial cancer.

Previously, healthy animals have only been released into the wild on Tasmania's Maria Island which did not have an existing population.

Late on Friday, 20 devils born in captivity were released into Narawntapu National Park, in the state's north, to join the area's wild population.

The animals are also the first to receive a specially developed vaccine to fight the disease.

It is seen as a potentially pivotal moment in the major fight to save the endangered species.

Every time this subject comes up I can't help but throw this idea out there. Should we really try to save Tasmanian devils? This species has obviously been marked by mother nature to be removed from this planet. If we follow the premise that it's wrong for human kind to alter the natural landscape, then this effort to save these animals is most certainly wrong. If you allow for saving these organisms, as a personal choice, you've opened the door to altering ecosystems based on the rule that if you want to do it, it's perfectly OK. Species go extinct all the time, with no help from us at all. This is one of the highest profile examples.
I feel the same way about those who fight forest fires that are not man made. Fire is a natural process. Some forests are in fact designed by mother nature to burn at fairly regular intervals. When the process is stopped, the forest can not be renewed.
Too many people expect the world to not change around them, when in fact change is inherent to the nature of this planet. I'm fairly certain that our role in the big picture is definitely not to put this world into stasis and make sure that nothing changes. Disagree if you will, but the last 4 billion years of evidence will back me up.

I wonder why the devil's immune system is not capable of sensing and destroying the cancer cells. The immune system should easily detect the foreign cells. However, there are two reasons for this coming to my mind. Either, the immune system is somehow inhibited by the tumor cells, maybe they release immune suppressing cytokines or something. Or the genetic diversity of the devils is so small, that the immune system cannot distinguish the foreign cells from its own cells (That's the reason why humans cannot be infected. If human cancer cells somehow come into your body it doesn't matter since your immune system will easily eliminate the cells before they can grow). If the second possibility is correct, there have to be some devils, which cannot be infected due to a higher difference in their genetics. This is a really interesting topic.

Hey Destin,

I wanted to ask a question (and it is alright if you do not know) about the causitive agent of this disease. All of my medical training in the area of communicable diseases have focused almost exclusively on microbes like a virus or bacterium. In this video, you mention that the mode of transmission is by the action of an infected Tasmanian devil biting a healthy Tasmanian devil, but there is not information on what causes it.

This could very well be different than human cancers which are all considered non-communicable for the most part but can be transferred by through something like a microbe like some of the papilloma or hepatitis viruses. Do you happen to know if it is literally the transfer of cancerous epithelial cells to another Tasmanian devil that is inducing neighbouring cells to then have enough genetic mutations to allow for tumour growth or is it rather the transfer of some kind of microbe that is ultimately leading to oncogenic changes?

So, let me get something straight, these cancer cells, which used to be the normal schwann cells of a regular Tasmanian Devil are acting just like a microorganism by infecting other individuals and spreading onwards... that is already pretty freaking fascinating. lt reminds me of the HeLa cell line from humans; if you are not aware of it, wikipedia it because it's insane, it wasn't transmissible like this cancer is, but they begun to replicate without the need to be in a human body, to this day we still use those cells even though we got them about 50 years ago.
Something l do find puzzling, l am aware that killing a species with a disease is almost impossible because eventually a certain percentage of the population is bound to have an innate immunity to it (evolution is known to leave pointless things laying around that after some time may become useful because of reasons) and they will have the advantage of having more food for them and they will repopulate and generate the same population, but with this added permanent inmunity... does this not work with the Tasmanian devils because: (Warning: hypotheses ahead, read under your own risk) their numbers are too small to expect a genetic variance or so small in fact that there aren't enough of them per square mile to be able to find a mate to reproduce? Does the fact that the 'microorganism' that causes the disease is so bizarre from our definition of one, that 'inmunity' may be a concept that doesn't even apply here? Are they inbred to a certain degree in which no individual is different enough to be able to have the inmunity? Do they have no parasite that alters their behaviour in such a way that they don't wish to be bitten by a member of their species? (this actually wouldn't apply because, if l understood it correctly, the disease is way too recent) Too many questions, not enough answers.
See people, this is why scientists study cancer in Tasmanian devils, some uneducated people may be like "How about you try to find a vaccine for human cancer!!!" but these scientists, by researching this disease, managed to also help with the diagnosis of human schwannomas. You never know what you're going to find when you study something that we know nothing about. :D

I don't know if a 'vaccine' will ever be effective. Tasmanian Devils have a very small genetic pool. A combination of isolation and later human culling has made this a very big problem. It's this genetic non-diversity that's made the tumor infectious in the first place, and the devils themselves have instinctual behaviors that facilitate transmission. Unless something drastic is proposed, like an island-wide quarantine of healthy devils (not that it would matter much, anyway, due to the genetic problems pointed out previously) and a culling of infected devils, or (and I'm squiking about how uncomfortable this makes me) a genetic alteration of the species itself... we'll likely only wind up with devils in zoos.
